review_title: Great co-workers - Fast Paced Work - Culture shift in 2020
pros:
The people you work with on a day to day basis are by and by excellent co-workers, and mostly friendly people. Throughout the majority of my stint doing a few different jobs at a couple of different locations it was one of the main consistencies I saw.

The work is also fast paced, which to some may be a negative, but for me it was just fast paced enough to make the day go by quick, but not to work you like a dog (although there were certainly days where it felt like it, nature of the beast though).

And this is case by case, but my branch managers (read: direct managers) were fantastic. They generally came from the ground up, and understood what it took to run a branch, while also working with people through any difficulties or changes. All of my direct managers understood that things happen and often times you just need a day, or maybe even a week away. Imagine this depends on the branch, but I saw it multiple times. They were also honest and fair about how to improve if there were any needed.
cons:
The largest issue is the micro-management. Where as I once felt like I had a say in day-to-day branch operations, by the end of it I was worried I was going to get my hand slapped for saying yes or no to any request that came through. It creates a toxic work environment and didn't lend itself well to morale or company culture. Keep in mind, this micro-management was NOT coming branch level managers, but from upper management aka district level management. It took every bit of fun out of the job.

Pay is also a huge issue. The raises are miniscule, are definitely not consistent with inflation, and they will flatly hire someone on with less skill than you and pay them 2.50 more. I know this, because it happened to me. It's a part of what led me to my new job.

That leads into the long days. I know for some M-F, 7-5 is not bad, but it's not for me. Too many times an issue comes up and you're expected to come in early, go in on a Saturday or stay way later than originally intended. Absolutely no work-life balance.

There's also not much diversity, so if that's what you want or look for in a company, you are not going to get it here.

review_title: After 12 years, continue to be amazed
pros: After 12 years I continue to be amazed by this organization. Hurricane Ida devastated Louisiana and left many team members in need of some basic necessities such as food, clothing, and shelter. United Rentals quickly provided many team members with grants that allowed them to purchase these basic necessities. Many homes were damaged and left uninhabitable - UR provided campers that accommodated entire families at no cost to team members. The United family sent canned goods and household supplies from across the country – enough that there was a pantry setup for all team members that had a need to get free food and groceries. Showers and laundry trailers were also made available to team members free of charge. While all this was amazing and much appreciated, what really exemplified United Rental’s culture was the team members that came in from across the country to help. Boots on the ground, taking care of people they had never met before but that didn’t matter, all that mattered was that we all belonged to the same family. The United Rental’s family! I was taken back by how many team members were so willing to give up their time to help those in need. That’s family, that’s culture, that’s UNITED RENTALS!!
cons: I haven't been able to meet all my family members - it's a big family.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Charlotte, NC
pros: Given a substantial amount of sick time, PTO time, and floating holidays. There is a incentive plan in place if you reach contract and conversion goal you can get paid out every 3 months. If you spend enough time here and meet your metrics you can have opportunities for growth in other departments of the company.
cons: I specifically worked at the Corporate National Call Center in Charlotte, NC. To start off the recruiters that hire you on for this role do not give you a good description of what the job entails. You think you are going into a sales job but it’s really just taking orders from customers. You are receiving incoming calls all day from customers that are either personal renters or companies, and they could be anywhere in the US or Canada. The training given does not prepare you for the calls you will get. Also, there is no consistent coaching and training to improve throughout your time there. They wait until you are doing poorly and then want to help. All branches have full autonomy whereas we have strict guidelines and processes that we have to follow. Also, the center has to work all major holidays but you are given more time that you can use to take off, but than that counts against you because if you don’t reach your sales goals it’s all on you. There is favoritism amongst employees and the micro managing here is overbearing. There is also a cap on the amount of money you can make from your “sales”. You are lucky if you make 35K a year. Some of the supervisors here are great but upper management is not willing to adapt.

pros: Good benefits, great co-workers, loved my job
cons:
Working at United Rentals for over 13 years was always high stress in every position of our branch. Workloads for employees were triple what they should be, often times doing the work of two or more departments.  

Upper management politics and poor HR staff only make matters worse. Stress is not properly managed. Employees quit or have a meltdown with no management or HR assistance . I watched the most excellent and talented co-workers, managers and outside sales staff leave the company due to stress or politics.  I myself requested a work from home option due to a new disability.  Not 'doable' even though by law you are allowed reasonable accommodation.  After 13 years of working my rear end off 55 hours a week they could not accommodate me for a few months.  My position would not have caused undue hardship working from home completing data entry one day per week.  I was told to take FMLA one day per week.  As usual, office politics made that situation go away.  I too, a hard working and loyal employee felt I had no choice but to leave. 

Management styles are very inconsistent.  Growth opportunities are for outside sales and upper management with degrees and clout only. Branch level jobs are dead ends. Empty promises. 

My advice? Don't ever get very sick or too stressed. They only pay you so much per hour and once you cap out they just don't care, even if you are a valued employee.

review_title: A Company Built for the People
pros: I am a big sports guy.  The Chicago Bulls of the 90s had Phil Jackson, the San Antonio Spurs have Greg Popovich, and the New England Patriots have Bill Belichick.  All were/are arguably the best teams with the best coach in their time and sport.  United Rentals has Matt Flannery coaching the best team in the industry.  I have been fortunate to hear Matt tell many stories of opportunities for leadership.  None better than his coaching experience with his daughter in basketball.  Any person should join this team just to hear that story.  It was very moving and very inspirational.  This company continues to make great strides at placing strong, humble leaders in strategic areas.   Leaders that are focused on your family, community, and your career.  As great as this company is, I really believe that even better days are still ahead of us.  I have been with United Rentals since 2001 and have a large family to support.  Regardless of the trials we will face, I feel very secure in United’s future and mine and my families.
cons: Like any family, there can be disagreements and this is a large family (Currently 19,000 strong).  However, the executive leadership team travels the country many times throughout the year to hear the voice of the people.  Most if not all of the solutions come from those meetings.

review_title:
If you can't beat them, buy them out!

I left on my own terms and am incredibly happy with my new job. Most of our management was laid off only to be replaced by overwhelming incompitence.

If you are okay with people forced to do business with you because you are the largest rental company in the United States,  then I guess their fleet size is a plus
cons:
After United bought RSC customer service was thrown out the window and all of us territory managers were sent out to essentially sell lies.  It was way more fun to compete against United rentals and dominate them rather than to work for such a selfish company.  They have absolutely no respect for their customers business nor for the employees working hard to build customer relationships.  RSC was growing rapidly ( due to a strong customer service culture), United realized they were a threat and added them to the list of companies they have taken down. 

The sliding pay scale is a joke and only a way to pay employees less. And just sets up the poorly trained ISR's to make customers mad by providing no consistency in pricing. 

United's equipment is junk and is just asking for a law suite when it hurts somebody for not being properly maintained.  

If fighting with your management on a daily basis to do what is RIGHT for your customer  -  fill out an application today!

job_title: Outside Sales Representative in Dallas, TX
pros: United Rentals is viewed by my customers as the leader in the industry.  It is a very professional company considering the types of customers we work with.
cons:
They are very generous when it comes to benefits, but I feel they lowball the base salary and do not give Outside Sales Representatives a fair commission percentage on rentals.  I say this because they require a Bachelors degree and outside sales experience.  The base is not in line with other companies in similar lines of business and do not make up for the extra night and weekend hours required to be successful.  

The company posts rates in our computers that are not in line with the market rates.  We are paid on a sliding scale commission that is reduced if we are forced to lower the rates below those posted in the computer.  In order to get any rentals out of the yard in this economy, we are forced to lower rates and therefore, will never get a full commission.  They should either go all commission and raise the rates to a flat rate or double the base salary and keep the sliding scale.  I do not fell fairly compensated for the amount of hours I work and the experience and skills that I bring to the company.

pros:
-Largest equipment rental provider in the world
-PTO
-401K
-Company vehicle (depending on position)
-Uncapped commissions
cons: United Rentals has the same pros and cons as most big companies do, and thus suffers from many of the same problems. You’re simply a number to UR. You basically mean nothing. With 15,000+ employees, they have no time or program for actually developing or investing in people. You will get little to no direction and will still be held accountable to those expectations. UR is also very much a “good old boys club.” Promotions occur based on who you know, and generally not what you know or how good you are at your job. Not to mention to “club” aids in protecting horrible employees. I know specifically of a leader within this company that has multiple terminable offenses, but because of the relationship with a “higher up” this employee continues to be shielded. If you are an OSR, there is a good chance that most of your sales goals are completely arbitrary. They make up sales quota numbers. There’s no MoM or YoY analysis - they basically create a blanket goal for everyone, despite what your market size/penetration/etc. might be. My experience was not a good one, and I would suggest you to keep looking elsewhere if you’re really considering a job at UR.

review_title: Not A Good Company To Work For
pros: Good Benefits, room to advance, generous emergency leave time, cares about employees safety, compassion fund
cons:
Takes advantage of employees, makes college interns perform duties that are not part of the internship, does not promote from within, does not care about life away from work, long hours, underpay employees not in management or sales, little acknowledgement from management, toxic work environment, outside all day, management nitpicks everything, outside sales do not pull their share of the workload, usually understaffed, nonethical business practices, no bonuses for hourly employees while management and sales get bonuses, gives the lowest paid people majority of the work, everything is a rush, when on call you can be called out anytime of the day, management does not hold up to their promises, threats to fire people over little mistakes, no incentives for hourly employees.

Not a good place to work if you are not in management or sales. You will be asked to do duties that are not in your job title with no additional pay or acknowledgement from management. If you are a tech, driver, or EA you will be treated as the bottom of the barrel. Inside sales also have a lot of pressure on them from management. They would rather quantity over quality. They care more about the customer than employee.

review_title: Overall good, lacks diversity and realistic viewpoint
pros: Great compensation and focus on safety. Industry leader is safety and technology. There is a the opportunity for advancement in a number of fields and also the company invest in being a industry leader. Company Car and high salary plus bonus.
cons: Too much of a "good ol boy" culture. Company makes attempts to become diversified but it is truly a lacking point. Union labor tends to be negative and older managements will cater to them in fear of retaliation sometimes. Often felt like an outsider where a few documented race based incidents reported to HR along with claims of ageism. Always felt like i was being watched by middle management and older labor who told me themselves that where moved to my location to watch over development. Hiring additional labor always seemed to move slow and it was frowned upon to look outside out district for help or resources. If you did the possibility of being scolded  was real. High stress constant environment seems to wear everyone thin from the top down and it always trickles.

review_title: Work 50 to 60 hours a week for a less then the industry average paycheck.
pros: Good benefits, a lot of freedom, set your own schedule. Good sales meetings, one of the largest in the industry, a lot of good people to work with.
cons: Upper Management is not in touch with the field, United is very slow to adapt to market trends. United’s rates are too high they are trying to rent gear and get the same rates they were getting 2 years ago when construction was still rolling. Sales reps are only as good as last month’s numbers. It’s very hard to get answers on important issues. It often feels like you are own a drifting ship. If you have a bad branch manager you will get almost no support. Expect to work 50 to 60 hours per week for a less then the industry average pay check. There commission plan is still largely based on a booming economy and not today’s economy. There rental fleet is aging and is starting to break down a lot. They have gone to the big brother system with there outside sales reps and delivery drivers. They track there sales reps every move via the laptops in there sales trucks.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Cheyenne, WY
pros: Lots to do all the time, great opportunity to develop relations with customers on a daily basis. Very busy constantly. Lots of opportunity to learn new things about a diverse industry. A somewhat reliable bonus program quarterly.
cons: Management is in complete disarray. Supervisors have a hard time balancing being a friend or being your boss, employees are hired simply to fill a space in order to help get things done even if that employee has no business being hired. Work constantly, from dawn till dark, and then on-call on the weekends. Bonus program is great when you hit all the marks, but one of the marks relies solely on the branch manager to set the bar for the quarter. If he/she sets the bar incorrectly, you are out of the money just like that, with no chance to get that extra money back. Tons of stress on a daily basis.

review_title: Unlimited Exposure to new things with limitless opportunity for development and advancement
job_title: Branch Manager in Saint Rose, LA
pros:
United Rentals seeks to promote those who work hard and are looking for long term career opportunities. The have training programs designed to develop their employee's and create bench strength for future growth and change. They are on the cusp of technology and are leading industry change for our business..

Personally, United Rentals has given me the training, support and development to help me advance in my career. I have experienced so many new things and have been exposed to so many new areas of the country and people because of United Rentals. I don’t believe I would ever had these opportunities and experiences with another company within our industry

United Rentals is a family friendly and safe company that provides me with the peace of mind I need to be a good provider to my family both from a financial and presence perspective
cons: I honestly cannot come up with any Cons with working for United Rentals. You get out of the company what you put into it. Works hard, be patient and the benefits will far outweigh any obstacles you may encounter along the way

pros: If you produce results you will keep your job. Good job to have if you like weekends off and don't want any hassle when it is time to request vacation. Set work schedule so planning off work activities is easy. The benefits are decent.
cons:
Most of the management all the way up to regional level is unaware what it really takes to grow market share in this very competitive industry.

Very subpar equipment compared to most of the competitors.

There is a good old boy culture that doesn't realize or understand the intelligence and needs of the current customer base.

Very shady hiring and firing practices. They will hire your replacement before you know your employment is terminated.

United is infested with people that produce no results and do very little on a daily basis but are still employed because they were hired when the money flowing in the door and they were able to take credit for the major economic growth.

The system of general rental and aerial divisions servicing the same projects and customers is a complete mess. If you work for general rental, the aerial division IS your competitor regardless of what management tells you.

The branches are hurting for fleet and are severely understaffed.

review_title: It used to be great.  Now not so much.
pros: Decent Benefits, decent pay. If you are in the rental industry UR is probably the best looking horse in the glue factory.
cons:
Almost all decision making has been stripped from branch managers and sent up the ladder.    Rate approvals for BM's are narrowed down to a very narrow range.  Paperwork/paperwork/paperwork.  If you aspire to be a BM, be sure you like to do clerical work first, otherwise stay in sales.  
What have you done for me lately atmosphere.

job_title: Outside Sales Representative in Houston, TX
pros:
-company truck w/ gas card    -Paycheck
-set you own schedule                -Advancement
-experience at a Fortune 500
cons: The rental business is very rough on sales people. Some have better accounts which helps, but most like me dread it. Here, not only are you an outside sales rep making sales call, finding new customer, quoting deals, making deals, and repeating. You’re also part manager, project manager, mechanic, inside sales, driver, laborer, and door mat. Might not be the same at every location, but we do not have the support we need to run a successful business and I work out of the largest store in the company. We have plenty of employees, but good luck getting someone to do anything that’s not their job. The culture is extremely toxic these days, with no one being able to make a decision on their own and no one having motivation to work. It really is a rough place to work right now.

review_title: Toxic industry, management will not work with employees, Salesforce is poorly used
pros:
Some really great people work for this company. 
The overall company culture is good but the work life balance is terrible. 
Compensation is reasonable
cons:
-Top heavy, managers to manage managers that manage managers. That is not an exaggeration, need to thin it out, and get managers that really care. 
-Everyone is overworked, and expect way to much of the employees. 
-Never feel like you are successful even when hitting numbers, it always seems like there is something you are doing wrong

-Salesforce is a great tool, but there is too much of an emphasis on it. Many companies use it, but United Rentals abuses it. Unrealistic expectations, and everyone is adding fluff.

review_title: Great opp for an aggressive college grad
pros: If you are interested in seeing how all that theory in college applies to real world business, then apply for an inside sales position. This is not for the faint of heart. You will see first hand how a business is ran from top to bottom. Best in class industry leader. I spent a long time here and have seen it improve time and time again. Do not go into this company thinking you will be a manager or a sales rep. You work hard and the company will reward you with the challenge you can handle.
cons:
You can jump into a hornets nest if you aren't careful. Meet with as many "managers" as possible. You will likely work 60 to 70 hours a week in peek season(spring-summer-fall).
Construction/Industrial industry is not very politically correct. They are ruff around the edges.

pros: URI offers competitive wages, and a good benefits package. The company's large size offers a reasonable amount of job security.
cons: URI's approach to business in the last three years has been to streamline, increase efficiency, and sell image - to Wall Street. All of these are great, unless done at the expense of quality of service. United has worked hard to differentiate itself from the competition, charging a higher rate for a better product. Unfortunately, they are still demanding a higher rate, but are now offering a substandard product. What was once a relationship-based business relying on repeat customers, is now transactional - we don't care if we upset a customer, there's another one around the corner.

review_title: Take sales personnel out of store manager bucket
job_title: Outside Sales Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: United has the most equipment, and the most customer touches of any company.  Therefore you are always guaranteed business.  You work for the little things in your territory. Then, when the big things show up, you still reap the benefits of a National Account Manager taking control of the situation, and you get the commission.  NICE.
cons:
Once that Nat Acct leaves, then you are on the hook for the lost revenue. Your idiot store manager, who is worried about drivers, front desk, service, conference calls, etc. is the one who come down on you with a double edge blade.  "Get more deals, but only the deals I like!"   Some, like the one I had, manage through ego, which ends in disaster for you as a rep.  If you complain to your DM, it will fall back on the manager to "deal" with you.  There is no open communication, no partnering with this person, just "listen to what I say, and I don't care what you do"  

Very focused on their own careers.

review_title: We were bought out, lied to, and then put out of a job.
pros: We actually did have the CEO come around to visit and they're operating systems were similar to what we had. They had a business plan.
cons: The CEO was touring which locations to shut down and lay off the employees and the employees that we had and they kept all say that they are very unorganized and no one wants to work as a team. When we were laid off they held a meeting on the company's status after the buyout and someone asked straight forward if there were going to be any job losses, they said no. We left the meeting and immediately after 2 people were called into the office and let go. So in my opinion they will always be liars and untrustworthy.

job_title: Customer Care Representative in Temple Terrace, FL
pros: Easy going call center. Calls were usually easy. We basically had to transfer most of them to the branch or sales department to handle. I barely dealt with irrate customers (which is great for a call center). The Manager was great, very approchable and nice. They gave us a set schedule, and were very flexible with it.
cons: They usually hire through a recruiter and don't bring you along until you get promoted to sales or another position. Had to work every Saturday (we all had to work atleast a Saturday or a Sunday each week). Had to work Holidays (although they were flexible with that too). Had to handle chats while on the phone, that was hard to do as people can't really multi task that way, you will always sacrifice the customer service from one or the other (usually the chat). Summer was VERY busy, calls were almost non stop until about end of September.

review_title: They invest in their people consistently...CEO is great.
pros:
It tells a lot about a company when the senior leadership has worked their way up through the ranks.  CEO Michael Kneeland built his entire career in the rental business--working on the front lines in sales and operations before he eventually made his way to the top job.  UR promotes from within and rewards their people for strong performance.

If you work hard, have good sales skills, embrace technology, collaborate well with others, and put the customers first, you will have a great career with UR.

I particularly like how they go out of their way to hire veterans, women, and minorities.
cons:
It's a big corporation now, so it comes with some of the corporate bureaucracy and inefficiency that all big companies have.  But compared to other similarly sized companies, UR is better than most when it comes to corporate BS.

Sometimes management can be a little too conservative and we lose opportunities to competitors that should have been ours.

review_title: Management ruin the company for me
pros: If they want you they will pay! During the flood company spared no time with assisting employees and family. Company also have opportunity for growth
cons: The the New Orleans/ Baton Rogue Metro its a good ol boy atmosphere.This area is run by saleman, if you question a salman who have been there a period of time because the salman want to give a customer a credit or a "loaner", you are pounced on through email as if you are not doing your job. Store managers do not hire employees upper management put extended family in positions that they are not qualified for. There are many family members that work in this area. Hiring has completely STOPPED, employees who have left have never been replace when it comes to drivers and mechanics, but they continue to hire salesman, who were fired form other companies. Managers are even dating employees this area in the time I have worked here is on a downward spiral.

review_title: Number one in the industry for a reason
pros: Great company to work for. They are growing and there is a lot of opportunity to advance. The have really embraced diversity and have a program for veterans. Pay and benefits are one of the best in the industry.
cons: The rules change as you go especially when it comes to commission and bonuses. I guess it's meant to keep you aiming higher but sometimes the goals are unrealistic. But the good pay balances it out so it's more of an inconvenience. The other downside is if you are a night owl. This industry is for early risers. 7am start time is the norm and sometimes earlier but thats the nature of the construction industry for most jobs. Sometimes that can be a problem balancing work with having school age kids unless you have support.

review_title: Great place to grow!  Hard work rewarded!
pros: It has enabled me to further expand my skill set and knowledge base!  I came to the company ready to work hard and let it be known that I was interested in growing and expanding my abilities.  I talked at length with the leadership of my department regarding my interests.  After working in my initial role for a year, I was able to successfully post for and move into a position with greater exposure and responsibility.  The new role has proven to be challenging, but very rewarding!  My continuing efforts to grow have been well supported by management.
cons: The company benefit of college assistance should be expanded from assistance for an undergraduate degree to obtaining graduate degrees.  Many of the corporate positions require a minimum of an undergrad degree so, this benefit really isn't useful to those who already have one.  Also, a company of this size should expand the current vacation benefits to better align themselves with many other corporations who award more time.

review_title: Your not an employee,  You are a number !!!!
pros: In the early years we  did what it took to take care of the customers.  The benefits are good and the people I work with make it a company I used to be proud to work for. Until recently I loved my job.
cons: Upper management does not care about you.  I was told that my position was eliminated and that  for my new position I needed to take a 30% pay cut.  I was notified on a Wednesday that it was in effect as of last Monday.   How about that for communication from management.  This company is going downhill on a daily basis and will not stop until they do something about the moral of the employees answering the phones.

review_title: United Rentals' biggest investment is in thier employees!
pros: The company takes time to recruit top level employees they can invest in. I believe the company can attribute a lot of its success by the way they treat thier people. Rather than feeling like you belong to a company, you feel more like you belong to a team and a family that you are very proud of, which makes you want to give just a little more everyday. Training and mentorship are never scarce, so you continually work with people who are helping you grow and improve professionally. Leadership is great, management is very knowledgeble and a good resource to learn from. UR also understands the importance of balancing home and work. They provide great benefits and programs to live a healthy lifestyle and really care about not only supporting each other, but everyone's families as well.
cons: United Rentals is a great company with plenty of opportunity for advancement. However, I believe the company could benefit by developing a more structured pathway for career goals.

review_title: Unprofessional Corporate Culture- CLIQUES, KNOW-IT-ALLS, and the list goes on...
pros:
Good pay. Industry leader.
Good benefits for the most part
Has potential to create an amazing company structure
cons: Company Culture, especially in corporate environment. It is shockingly the worst work environment I've ever seen. Short cuts are constantly taken on reports, violating procedures, HR dept. makes no sense in structure, "good ol boys" type culture, no one opinion matters unless your senior level. No trust is given to employees. All big ideas, no execution.

job_title: Senior Inside Sales Representative in New York, NY
pros: Competitive compensation, college reimbursement, overtime during busy season, opportunity to get training, locations all over the U.S., can advance if hard-working, good at social networking, and patient...really patient
cons: Can be stressful, lots of initiatives from corporate some aren't great, equipment has to be turned quickly to keep utilization high, sometimes it can be hard to find equipment for customers, scheduling deliveries can be hard due to limited trucks. Staffed a little on the light side making vacations in summer tough

review_title: Great company to work for if it is staffed correctly and ready for operation!
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Ludlow, MA
pros: Military friendly company. Bonuses each quarter determining store performance. Paid for uniforms and boots. Great training if needed. Get a phone and lab top.
cons: For what needs to be done the pay is below par doing research on other companies. Get bounced around to doing call center and working at other stores due to be always short employees. Inside Sales is responsible for a lot and has to cover down on making decisions if manager is unfit to. Everything is last minute and can get a call anytime even on your time off. Very stressful working environment if everyone is not on the same page. Seems employees are just thrown into positions without the knowledge and training to see if that person will stick in that particular job.

review_title: It doesn't matter how much money you make for them, in the end you will lose out to the Politics!
pros: Good benefits: medical, dental and perks.
cons:
This company is truly a "House Divided" Aerial Managers and reps are treated like Gods while harding working General Rental Managers and Reps are treated like dirt. Time and time again General Rental reps achieve higher rental rates and have a much broader customer base and they are still referred to as second class employees. It truly amazed me how much money I made for that company year in and year out (bonus for 2006, 2007, 2008) and to be blown out in Q1 2009!!! This company rewards those who have lost them money instead of those who have made them money!!! I find it hilarious almost a year later to see how much worse it has gotten here in Detroit! As of this date, the Aerial division, which previously LOST MILLIONS for UR in Michigan, is now in charge! Talk about rewarding incompetency! 
UR is not a good place to work unless you have been buddies with upper management for many years.

You reap what you sew. Potential employees beware!

review_title: Glad to be gone from United Rentals!
pros:
- Pay used to be good but mgmt. changed that
- Had really good benefits in the past
- Had a company vehicle (really scratching for pros!)
- Good co-workers
cons:
- Incompetent, foul-mouthed managers that work on the bullying method.  There were some really good managers but they were forced out.  If you were fired by a competitor you were always welcome as a manager at UR.
- Non-stop worthless meetings at all hours.  Mid-day meetings that killed sales planning.
- 1980's IT Dept. still using DOS based IBM AS400 system.  In 2009 they added a terrible sales reporting program that added two hours to every day and was just a baby-sitting program.
- Long range planning consisted of today's stock price!
- Flip-flopped constantly (rate-leader, rate-matcher, contractor supply division)

job_title: Declined to Answer in Detroit, MI
pros: Great management of "image and story" to Wall Street since RSC merger.  Stock has outperformed.  Debt is dropping, share buy back was a stellar move, growth is controlled and management has greatly improved financial discipline.   $100/ share by 2015!
cons: 1970's Management approach at local, district and region levels.  Reactive field management style won't change - not sure that it should.   Questionable ethics still haunt URI at high levels, but Wall Street has much higher tolerance for ethical scandals compared to 1990s.

review_title: It's who you know, not what you know.
pros:
Good Pay and benefits
Large fleet
Nation account client base made up a significant portion of revenue
cons:
Most mid-level management (District Manager and above) were self-promoting and only cared about their own success and ability to be promoted. A lot of decisions were made, and a lot of great people lost due to short term thinking and decisions because they were scared for their own jobs.
District and Regional management were often deceitful and misled branch employees.
Bonus that were earned were cut. Some benefits were taken away, and pay has been frozen or very minimal pay increases. Meanwhile, the company has seen record results.

review_title: Fine, until the bean counters took over.
pros:
A good name and respected in the industry.

Decent fleet of equipment.

Fairly good community involvement.

Highly experienced qualified people who absolutely know their business.
cons:
Became highly micro managed.  It seems mangements goal is to see how many hours and production they can force out of people by insisting on mandatory meetings at 6:30 am so as to not impact the business day.  Mandatory Debriefing everyday at 5:30 to go over the days sales calls, asking who was seen, what was discussed and what is your plan for the next call on this customer.
It got to where we were making reports about reports, meetings about reports.  The paper work that had to be completed became more important than serving the customer and renting equipment. So I quit.

pros: Benefits are really great. Everything else is a sales pitch!
cons: There is no substance to any of their core values. Their polished image & propaganda to promote that image is in reality the complete opposite of how they treat their current & the reason for such a high turnover rate. They do not value individuality and try to group everyone into sales categories. It is a very political environment meaning if you express concerns or issues for anyone in their popular sect, you will not only be ignored but you will also be targeted & ultimately run off. Currently they are bordering on age discrimination with their hiring practices as they are actively recruiting college graduates & replacing older employees with these new hires. No personal communication with anyone in corporate and you literally have no support if you voice any concerns that isn’t inline with their agenda, which has resulted in a poor product & service to their customers.

pros: They have excellent benefits and most of your co-workers are fun and easy to get a long with.  They do have opportunities for growth in just about every state nation wide.
cons: During the recession, they have taken advantage of their employees quite a bit.  We understand that we've shut down businesses and had to eliminate people, but it has been 4 years since our last 'real' raise.  On top of that, with all of the lay-offs, one person is doing the work of 3.  Incentive programs have been eliminated unless you are in upper management.  They still get their bonuses.  In a better economy, it's not all bad.  With the recession, this job will burn you out.....

review_title: Great company if you are in the right location (management wise).
pros: Great benefits. Good opportunity for advancement if you are willing to lead the right way. Strong company vision is shared from top down. High wages compared to the competition, but a lot more is expected as well. Safety culture is very strong.
cons: Too much disparity between leadership from region to region. In the South (TX, OK, AR,) upper management is comitted to open communication, training, employee first management, and was still able to deliver company financial goals. In other areas management governs with an iron fist, zero tolerance, and fear. The latter being very disappointing when one has been party to the former.

review_title: Don't count on respect or honesty
pros: Medical coverage is good, Sick time is average. Paycheck hasn't bounced, yet.
cons:
Dental and Vision plans are a joke, I was told by benefits that I live "Out of Network" and such have no coverage, but they enjoy charging me for it anyhow. If you are a driver, there is no chance for advancement without taking a PAY CUT to go into inside sales. Branch management is largely incompetent and richly awarded for it. 

Was told by Branch management as well as my former Dispatcher that there were not going to be raises again this year due to budget cuts, but they may be available in June or July of 2011. I just received a letter from Corporate that Merritt Raises HAD been re-instated already. If you like being told to violate HOS, Lied to about raises, and poor maintenance practices, go ahead and apply.

review_title: A culture of favoritism, and cover-ups.
pros: The salary and benefits are good.
cons: The upper management thinks they can set nationwide policies and procedures that will fit all 600 branches of the company, regardless of the markets. They have everything they do written down in policy and procedure bulletins, but the rules are routinely ignored, and if you report it you are subject to retaliation by your manager. They just eliminated another batch of people, and they picked some of the best people to get rid of, thinking they can get the same job done with less people, or that they can hire idiots for less money. We'll see how it works for them.

pros: This company offers a vast amount of priceless sales training. Highly invested into employer safety inside and outside of work. Constantly improving through good communication between employer & employee. I sent a suggestion through my.ur.com, and William Plummer (CFO) personally replied. Free lunch every Friday. Well trained and seasoned branch managers. Close contact to all branch , district , and some regional personnel. If you work hard you can make it far in this company. The quartet bonus system for the IRS position is AMAZING. High end between $1200-$1600 per quarter. "Special ops" opportunities worth 25% more income for temporarily relocating, including paid housing / free flights every 3 weeks...etc. So much opportunity here.
cons: I do not like corporate mentality. Why can't I wear jeans? I don't agree with everything being "professional". We work directly with some of the roughest crowd out there..construction industry. Relax a bit.

pros: Senior Leadership is engaged, caring and responsive to everyone. Opportunity for growth is tremendous.  Training is available for everyone. Strong safety culture. Strong community outreach. Organization is there for everyone in time of need both professional and personal.
cons: I do not have any cons- The organization always looking for innovate and smart ways to grow and improve.

review_title: Great company to be a part of.
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Whitecourt, AB
pros: It is fast-paced, challenging and keeps you on your toes.  Always learning new things each and every day.  A wonderful team to be a part of.
cons: Some of the management is difficult to work for.  Some have a very "corporate mindset" and will only give you attention should you worship the ground they walk on.

pros: Compensations and benefits were good. Met some other good sales associates on the job.
cons: Lots and lots of micromanagement! There are more graphs and charts to tell you how to do your job then the stock market. If you come to the table with a book of business worth 2-3 million dollars. United will have you input every contact you know.  They will also need you to record every site and office visit with names, dates etc.,  into their computer software program Salesforce. You`re confined to a small territory and become a puppet for the big corporate machine.  Now when you leave be prepared to get a rash of lawyer letters threatening to sue you if you join the competition.  The American way, sue everything.

review_title: United Rentals provides me with a career path, goals, and a sense of achievement.
pros:
Experienced, strong leaders
Vision for the future
Truly believes in partnership with customers, not just supplier/purchaser relationships
Encourages leaders to recognize and develop talent
cons: There aren't many cons for me. I've experienced dramatic swings in the economic situation, and those fluctuations have taken us from one extreme to another, with risks at both ends. A couple years ago, we had hiring freezes, layoffs, consolidations, etc and now we're growing fast that it's difficult to maintain a high level of service without the infrastructure supporting current activities.

review_title: Laid off after 11+ years in 2009 & wish URI would rehire laid off employees!
pros: I loved working at URI because of the company benefits, values and mission. I knew that Mike and Matt would take this company to the top, which they did.  My skills were honed at this company. I had a great manager who taught me so much. Working at URI were the happiest and proudest days of my life.
cons: Not much room for advancement for women at our location. I honestly thought URI genuinely cared about long time employees but I believe the old adage "out of sight, out of mind" applies now that the company has grown so large.

pros: Made lots of money and friends
cons: Management is not good in this company.

review_title: Great company bad leadership in certain districts
job_title: Outside Sales Representative in Memphis, TN
pros:
Great benefits, with several perks such as company truck, phone and ETC... 

Great place to work if they don’t micro manage. 

Commission structure is great. 

Goals can be reasonable to attain.
cons:
Micro-management to the 10th power. 
Bad decision by management, made on who management likes better. 
Pushes education to certain people to get a particular position but others will get the position if their friends or family. 
Deserving people will get looked over. 
Too many favorites 
And a large amount of Nepotism and cronyism. Mostly seen in the Mississippi-Tenn area like nephews getting hired with no proper background in sales over deserving people who’ve been with the company for years.

pros: Pay and benefits at UR are very good.  Easy in sales to earn six figures and to expand your skill set.  Branch level management (at least mine) cared about you as an employee.  Specialized divisions means you always had a line that could benefit a customer.
cons: A overall sales outlook of burn and turn.  Salesforce is used like a sledge hammer and just adds to busy work despite your performance.  Beyond branch level is out of touch with local markets and ticking all the boxes is what matters.

review_title: No original thinkers wanted, only sycophants need apply
pros:
The salary structure is competetive. The medical, dental and vision benefits are very good. The large number of locations provides opportunities for advancement and also the ability to relocate.
There are areas where the company has benefitted from good personnel and strong leadership, it is in these locations where it is possible a enjoyable and successful career with a single company.
cons:
In some districts advancement depends on favoritism and kowtowing over ability and experience. This company is losing a lot of talented employees to their competition because of poor management.
Policies are selectivly enforced. Safety is preached but often overlooked when it conflicts with profitability or expediance.

job_title: Outside Sales Trench Safety in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Benefits, job security, a good learning stepping stone.
cons: It feels wrong to rip off customers. We do this daily. Either we are ripping off our customers for a quick buck or slipping one past our DM so the customer makes a quick buck. Either way, and I'm uncomfortable. Culture is awful and abusive. I was told if I didn't like the sales territories, "Apply elsewhere and we'll sue you for enforcement of your non-compete." This came true for the last guy so I'm kind of scared. We quote projects at low rates, with no idea of how to accomplish the job. This makes me feel like any day we will be exposed.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Charlotte, NC
pros: Salaries are good overall. Great benefits.
cons: Older employees tend to be first to go during a head count issue, business downturn, etc. Company is very youth minded, focusing on the future of the company. When you cross into your 50's, watch out. You no longer represent the future for the company, and you are at a greater risk to be moved out as soon as a reason can be found other than discrimination. Older applicants with years of experience always lose out to younger college grads with no experience in the business. Very costly.

review_title: United Rentals is forward-thinking and always evolving.
pros: There is a lot of freedom to take ownership of ideas and projects. I feel like I make a difference and get recognition for my efforts. The company genuinely cares about the people who work here on a business level and on a personal level.
cons: Things are continually changing as the company grows. While there are efforts in place to train employees and communicate evolving policies, it is challenging to stay current on all topics or to find some of the answers that you need.

job_title: Outside Sales Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: We work as a team, everyone from service to sales. Our employees are passionate about what we do and we are confident that we will get the job done. If we don’t know how, we will find out how and make it happen. I love our team!
cons: United Rentals likes to change how they do things quite often. Change can be hard, especially if you are set in your ways. However, the change is always for good reason.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Trench Safety devision is the most profitable. It's not rocket science. Regardless of your geographical location every single contractor/prospective customer is similar in the fact that they are on a tight schedule and are wanting a solid service along with superb equipment. URI has that plus some.
cons:
Drivers - Being an ISR requires constant attention towards customers and drivers (aka dispatch). Don't allow the jerk off drivers to affect your mood. 

I work 50 hours a week. Not much time for weekday activities. Honestly I would rather have a good pay check than 4 extra hours during the week. "Everybody's workingfor the weekend!"

review_title: Its a Career, not a Job
job_title: Outside Sales Representative in Demopolis, AL
pros: United Rentals feels like family, not coworkers. Even though we are a company of over 16,000, it feels like everybody knows your name. Upper management cares about their employees. We work together with a mantra of ONE UR. There is nothing that could tear us apart. Its not that I haven't met all of my UR family, its that I haven't met all of my UR family YET. We have an amazing safety culture. Each morning we start off with a safety meeting and do meta-postures.
cons: You work long hours, but you are well compensated for it. Depending on what job you take with the company, it can be dangerous. No matter how safety conscious we are, we work in a very dangerous industry and accidents can happen.

review_title: Great if you're in a good district/good branch-too many particiation tropy leaders
pros:
Solid hours, benefits, compensation
Some really great people
Growth is possible
cons:
To grow you have to either know someone in the in-crowd or hang the moon as you get to know them.
You can bring ideas forward that are shut down over and over and then presented to you by your boss 3 weeks later as some grand plan they've concocted.

Too many people in positions because they fit the profile for what UR wants in diversity...not necessarily because they do the job. You have people who failed as sales reps holding management positions. You have "clique" favorites that pretty much run the show in some regards.

job_title: Senior Shared Services Specialist in Temple Terrace, FL
pros: I've worked at United Rentals a few times over the years in their corporate office. They have been a fair and honest employer for years, and even when their plans required changing in the local staff, they often spoke months ahead of time of the plans. It's disappointing to separate from a company you like but the open honesty about upcoming major changes were refreshing.
cons: Corporate environment was limited a great deal by the branch environment. Not uncommon but it would have had better interactions from an employee standpoint if they didn't tether policies to match both corporate offices and branch locations.

review_title: Culture and Opportunities within United Rentals
pros: They value you as an employee and take time to assess your personal situation and find the best solution for you. Whether its spending time with family during the holidays or a tough day at work, management at United Rentals  makes time for you. There's a lot of opportunity for growth and upward mobility.
cons: Although I really like current management within the Sales Development Program,  one of the managers can contribute to a negative work environment. I feel as though United Rentals could be more inclusive within the corporate climate with diversity.

review_title: Reactive not proactive management from above
job_title: Outside Sales Representative in Silver Spring, MD
pros: Lots of freedom, company truck, get paid for the work, you get out of it what you put in.
cons: Management from above & will never see them lead by example. No HR presence at all, so superiors get away with whatever they want and use scare tactics. Have slesforce.com but they have no clue how to use it properly in such a fast pace environment. Don't expect a happy work environment. Were so far behind the curve in technology they bought out their largest competitor because they had no clue how to catch up.

review_title: Definitely the leader among its competitors
pros: United keeps growing and has a great way of keeping the people throughout the acquisition process. Every branch you go to you feel like they are a family and that is difficult to do in such a large company. They really strive to achieve the highest standard of customer service and provide the proper training to their employees.
cons: If you weren't around when the company first started it is difficult to grow unless you have someone in your corner. If you are valuable you may find yourself in a position longer than expected. Although they are a leader in their industry there are still a lot of room to within the culture and the technology.

review_title: A great work environment, fun, challenging & rewarding.
pros: UR invests heavily in its people and lets you do your job. Even though it's a massive corporation you still get the feeling that your voice is being heard. This is especially nice when it comes to being part of the strategy side of a business.
cons: The only down side I have experienced so far is that for a diverse company we try to use a "one size fits all" approach to running the business units.

pros: Large company that has great healthcare and a focus on the customer and safety. Nationwide so the are plenty of opportunities from coast to coast at all levels of experience.
cons: Sales to be a focus for upward mobility, without time as a salesperson the climbing of the corporate ladder is limited. Also while being part of a large company can be a pro, the con is you're more of a number.

pros: Company vehicle with gas card, expense account, great guys to work for at the branch level, good customer service to their customers, largest rental company so good brand recognition, good training's.
cons: Pay, hours, micromanagement, too much middle management, to many reps per territory, typical corporate company atmosphere, meaning you are just a number and treated as such. they expect you to be in the field at around 6:30 am until 6:30 pm and then spend a couple hours a day on the computer for about $45,000 a year.

job_title: Outside Sales Representative in Norman, OK
pros: Their are several good people here within my district. Continuing to grow which can open up opportunities for personal growth if wanted.
cons: Too many layers of management. Some are fine while others are not on the same page as to what needs to happen within their own district. Can be difficult to move up if you do too good of a job at your current position. Some districts seem to have too many people looking out for themselves and their own agenda rather than working to build a good team.

pros: Good pay, good benefits. I believe corporate and the CEO have the right idea. I think that they need to monitor branches and get rid of bad managers.
cons: As with another reviewer. I work at a good ole boy branch. With the Favoritism and all the other isms. You advance with total allegiance to the manager. Management has complete disconnect with the ones who do the work. Safety is a big concern. I put this in the cons as I grew up in the time when safety was your responsibility, So don't like the safety gestapo. United Rentals is no different than any other corporation in this respect.

job_title: Seevice Tech in San Francisco, CA
pros: Really good benefits and retirement plan 401k, stock shares are tremendous, they will train you with their pump division team and power and Hvac I’m not sure with general tools and trench because I was not working on their side, but good company to work for if your not weak and lazy
cons: Tasks are always given make sure you know your line of work. working hard will challenge you for more and more tasks to test your knowledge and work ethic. Employees are very competitive with each other so stay in your line and work very hard

pros: Large company with good benefits. There are a lot of good hard working people who do there jobs to the best of there abilities.
cons:
United rentals has become so focused on the way the company appears to stock holders and trying to get new investors by cutting costs and raising it's roca score that the equipment fleet has really gone down hill.
Rushed inspections of equipment and the whole "if it ain't broke don't fix it" attitude toward preventive maintenance has resulted in a overwhelming number of junk being sent out on rent.

review_title: United Rentals, a dynamic environment that is filled with positive opportunities every day.
pros: Every day at United Rentals is different. You really apply core business principles on a daily basis. A great environment to establish long term relationships with fellow staff and clients alike. People who thirve on a fast pace environment and embrace change will love United Rentals.
cons: Change at United Rentals is constant. United Rentals measures and tracks performance at all levels, all the time. It's an environment that keeps you on your toes and makes you bring your "A" game to work every day. I wouldn't have it any other way!

job_title: Branch Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great Company to work for.  There is a lot of opportunity if you are open for it.  Many different directions to move your career.  This is a company where you are truly measured by your accomplishments and the only limits are those you set on yourself.
cons: If you don't like change this is not the place for you.  If you don't like the way things are, wait a month or two and it will probably change.

pros: United Rentals was my favorite job.  Our manager Hillary was amazing and as a team we all worked together to meet our monthly goals and if one was falling behind everyone would help as a team should (including our manager).  She not only rewarded us for our hard work, the whole department felt like family and it was a sad day when we all heard the news in regards to the fate of our department.
cons: The whole department was let go without a warning.

pros: Days go by really fast... Worked out of a few different branches now and every one of them was extraordinarily busy.  Have met a lot of great people and friends through working here.
cons: Most of the reason that days go by fast is that management goes with a bare bones staff at every branch almost to a T.  I have worked out of a few locations and you always felt swamped and when you talked to other branches they would always say the same thing.  Training program is terrible, no real way to learn what it is that you are actually selling.  In order to move up,  you are likely going to have to move around a lot.

pros: I was recruited by United Rentals at my university's career fair to work in their corporate office in Charlotte, NC. My position was a sales associate in an OSR (outside sales representative) training program. I made roughly 60-80 phone calls to dormant accounts all over the US, east coast to west coast, as well as Canada. Great experience making cold calls, working with sales force software, and building a pipeline to manage my customers. I rented equipment, sold training, and passed leads for used equipment sales.
cons: I was told that the program was 6 months and then I will be able to interview and be promoted as an OSR. I know many people in the program that were there for a year, the average time in the program was 8-11 months.

review_title: it is all about the share holders.  Not the workers and their interests.
pros: Not a bad place to work, but understaffed and over managed.  Not much room for promotion in my branch.  The good things are the vacation and the health benefits.  2 weeks vaca off the bat, 401k, which was just reduced.  Vision and dental and good pay raises.
cons: Please see above, i guess i should have looked first.  No pay raises, market instability has been a huge problem with the recent down turn.  The company micro manages you to death, and the 401K is gone.  Massive lay offs in recent year and result as spead exisiting people so thin that it is hard to get much done with out being frustrated.

review_title: Busy, Busy, Busy never ending work...
pros: #1 The benefits - full dental, eyes, medical 401k, paid vacations, six paid sick days, three floating (birthday, Anniversary DOH +1 more). Mediocre annual training. Fairly competitive pay.
cons: Must own tools, inability to take vacation when company is busy (summer). No real opportunity for advancement, once you have a job it's hard to transfer to another location or level ie sales. Feel stuck, need to be "customer oriented" when dealing with ignorant users (read: Dumb people). Pay raises seem to be mere cost of living adjustments versus raise. Must have two sets of tools (you are a shop and road tech)

review_title: You can make a lot of money, but you do it by jumping from one crisis to another.
job_title: Service Tech IV in Mickleton, NJ
pros: Different stuff every day, lots (!LOTS) of overtime, interesting situations.
cons: As an operations (driver or technician) employee, it is easy to get the feeling that corporate wishes they could just subcontract your entire department.  Only sales and management get any recognition or development, and it can be very challenging to move from ops to sales.  Also, when you rely on overtime, things like vacations or illnesses can devastate your income.  You will always be running two steps behind, without the proper training or tools to do the job right.

review_title: United needs to step up their game if u want your employees to stay.
pros: They feed u if u go to training.
cons:
Pay is NOT up to par......mabye for sales but no one else.
Lots of micromanaging.
Managers won't enforce their own rules or company rules.
They feed u enough BS to keep u hanging on
Lots of broken promises.
You can't take someone for their word.
Management gets restaurant food and goes out having fun for training.....hourly gets stuck in a classroom for 8 hours listening to speeches and watching short videos.
You get docked one hour if u don't take lunch.
All conversations are done by email......but don't expect a reply when u really need one.

review_title: 18 plus years vs Good Olde Boy System!
pros: Good Benefits, PTO, Vacation, Great Safety Visions for workers & Family also Some Good People to work with & Great Customers
cons: Only Complaint is decisions made on the "The Good olde Boy System" & not on actual proven track record. Tip on Post employment issues with HR are to get all your answers you need before signing your release forms cause you can hang it up getting ANY answers after signing.

review_title: Position should be secretary not inside sales rep
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Martinez, CA
pros:
Decent pay and quarterly bonuses depending on branches profit. 
No degree required
40 hour weeks
No weekends 
Largest rental company in the industry
cons:
Constant racist, sexual and other inappropriate  remarks  in office about customers and employees. The office was extremely uunprofessional. 

Disconnect from management. No clear direction

Inside sales role  but the job does not involve sales. Daily duties were more like a secretary.  Take orders on phone, clean out trash, make coffee and transfer calls.


Manager is unapproachable 

New hire trainings didn’t happen for 3 months and didn’t apply to my office because each office makes exceptions on whichever rules they please

Overall I would not recommend this job. I have never worked in a office so unprofessional. Coming from a customer service and sales background I am surprised how such a large business can provide such poor customer service. Employees are rude to customers across the board.

pros:
Management is very good, leaders are open, and part of a great team atmosphere. 

If you want to work hard, and learn the business, leadership will invest in you and will support you. 

Great company to work for business wise, and have a very good work life balance.
cons: None as of right now.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in McAlester, OK
pros: Good benefits, friendly Co workers, good pay, family friendly, opportunity for advancement and safe work environment.
cons: Went through 6 managers in 6 years, I have ran location with remote management that came to get paperwork maybe once a week and was little help with issues concerning my location, I've had to train new managers.Also working counter can sometimes get overwelming with management unlikely to help. My last manager tried to change and add to my job roll to the point I couldn't do it.

review_title: Solid executive team, solid strategy, pay for performance
pros: Company rewards pay for performance.  Executive team is passionate about customer service, continuous improvement, and the organization is very dynamic.  Corporate and field career opportunities have increased with growth of company footprint.  Engagement surveys and quarterly calls show commitment to employee feedback.  Systems and technology investment is large to make the UR the rental industry leader in this area.  A large company but the feel is that of a large family.  I'm 14 years with the Company and am very proud to speak about the Company to anyone I meet.
cons: With any large Company, coordination and internal communication can be challenging. The Company recognizes this and tries to be proactive on communications.

pros: Flexible and self-determined hours, 401K and health care options.  Perks of having a company truck, fuel card, expense card, laptop, and iPhone.
cons: The upper level management does not care about the OSR, you are only a number to the corporate structure.  This position is all about what territory you are assigned with.  If you get assigned a good territory, then this place would be worth working at.  However, if you are in a bad territory, there is simply nothing you can do.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Washington, DC
pros:
Decent benefits 
Decent pay
Decent perks 
Overall not a bad place to start a career but wouldn't recommend finishing one there. I've been looking for a door for years. I got stuck when I was younger. I recommend coming in learning the trade and moving on.
cons: No work life balance to speak of. Used to have to work Saturdays but not anymore (although a few stores are still open then). Pay is okay but not great. Long hours sometimes. Getting to work at 6 and leaving at 6-7 is not a good way to keep happy employees.

review_title: Out with the old, In with the new.
pros: United Rentals posseses the size and footprint to dominate the market.
cons:
United Rentals has forgotten the ABC's of rental and is trying to re-invent the wheel.
Too many changes/elimination in management and experienced employees has reduced their knowlege in this industry, as a result they are making the same mistakes that have already been learned in the past.
Most of the employees do not trust mid and upper management due to the continual turnover and will jump at the opporunity to work for the competition.

job_title: Service Tech IV in Denton, TX
pros:
Most Employees were very good to deal with
Great benefits
Close to home
cons:
Very difficult to move up in the company
Would be required to work long hours in a day, or be "on call" and if you got called out in the middle of the night for say 4 hours, instead of paying you overtime they would require you to come in 4 hours late 2 days after you were called out.
There was nothing to make you want to be there, they removed all employee perks.
Very poor Management. 
Pay was minimal for the work done. (i've worked at places with less pay and were a100 times more enjoyable)

review_title: Great Place To Work and Learn
job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Edmonton, AB
pros:
- Great Team to work with
- Had Fun
- Good Pay compared to other industries
cons:
- Due to the downturn in the economy, there were many lay offs and for the staff members who were left, they had to pick up the slack.
- Work life balance is a challenge.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Unlimited Earning Potential
Wide Range of Equipment and Services
Plenty of support
cons:
Chargebacks on unpaid customer bills - can't do much about this.
Commission is also dependent upon the service that is provided. As sales, you can only do so much. Take care of your service  team.

pros: At the time I enjoyed the opportunity of working for United Rentals. I feel the company was understanding of people with small children and would let my hours be flexible. Considering I was in sales it was a great opportunity to work on my time and essentially create my own hours. Most of the time they were very flexible in this area.
cons: Working in sales with this company I sometimes had to work longer than normal hours for myself and with small children that became an issue.

review_title: URI is a fast paced, constantly evolving company that is always driving poistive change!
pros:
The safety culture is second to none.  
The diversity in the workplace is awesome, and the senior management support in this area is strong.
Operations are performing very well with much more room for continued profitable growth.
cons:
Work like balance can be tough to manage as we all work very hard, but it is fulfilling work.
The industry is cyclical, while things are great now there will eventually be lean days again.

pros: Benefits are comparable to the industry, Bonuses offered, Networking opportunities, lots of charitable work to assist with for the community. Company pays for training and travel. Networking throughout the branches for equipment and needs. Company has several growth opportunities for individual aspiration.
cons: Numerous meetings that bottleneck progress at the customer service level. Innumerable metrics to meet. Augmented micromanagement through emails and phone calls. High stress becomes an everyday factor. As with any job, if one is looking to be promoted it's all in connections not necessary personal ability to do a job to be able to excel above entry level. Must also be willing to transfer to have opportunity above entry level.

pros: Pay can be good if you are in a good territory.  Decent benefits.  Company Truck
cons: Territory Based sales position.   If there is work being done in your territory you could potentially do well. If there isn't, you probably won't.   Nothing proprietary about what United does.  You could have up to 20 competitors selling the exact same thing as you, typically at a much lower rate.   Recent mergers and acquisitions have added challenges in the field for reps, often phasing out older tenured reps.

review_title: United Rentals, Not a good place to work!
pros: A good overall benefits package
cons: Good old boy atmosphere prevails, good pay raises given only to employes that are close friends of Management. Promotions, forget it! Your reward for trying to do a good job to the best of your ability will be getting laid off so they can replace you with somebody less qualified. You are given a set of rules to follow when inspecting rental equipment for reuse after it has been returned however these rules are often side stepped in order to get equipment back out and rented. These problems are just the tip of the iceberg.

review_title: This is not an Acquisition.. Its a Merger..
pros:
Good pay
In my office, great managers who care about you and what you do.
No weekends
cons:
Since the acquisition with RSC, United Rentals has taken on their policies and their people. Upper management are pushing out the United Rentals people and replacing with RSC people. 
"Too many chief's, not enough indians".
Not enough people to actually do the job. hiring freeze.
micromanagement
Upper management does not listen to the people that actually work.

pros: Depending on the area, working at United Rentals can be very fast paced and profitable. If you are in an area with a growing economy, there will always be people and companies needing equipment for construction. You are able to get experience in a wide area of fields, including purchasing, inventory management, and logistics.
cons: United Rentals seems strangely averse to investing in decent technology. Proprietary application used for 100% of work activities is deeply powerful, but cumbersome, out of date, and poorly maintained. Inside Sales Reps have access to a quarterly bonus program, but have relatively limited ability to actually affect payout as total amount is tied to both overall location performance as well as district performance.

pros: I cannot think of any because the company ins terrible.
cons: They hired me as a driver, yet they made me clean garbages and sweep the shop floor for first month. They present themselves as a large company which has lots of oppurtuniites to grow but they really do not. They are cheapest company I have worked for and shove saftey down your throat to protect there own self interest. At the end of the day, they do not care about your saftey at all. Training took about a month and I kearned nothing. They are constantly changing everything you do on a daily basis so do not think about making a schedule. I do not have anything postive to say about this company. The managment is very consending and it is the worst company ihave ever worked for.

pros: Company rewards those that work hard and produce results.  Good pay and Benefits.  Management has done a good job navigating the company though the down turn.  United Rentals is the industry leaders and is improving every day.
cons: Not really any big cons to speak of.  There were a lot of people that lost their jobs in the last two years but the company had to do what it could to survive.  This is no different than most other companies given the economy.

review_title: Sales, Operations, Logistics, Purchasing, HR, Negotiation, Contracts, AR, and so much more...
pros: United offers a singular opportunity for someone who doesn't need their hand held to learn a lot about business. They are well managed from a strategic level. As with most firms that are not in the top "50 greatest places to work", you will witness the good, the bad, and the ugly. More good than bad and most of us are ugly. Take the plunge. Great company to learn the ropes!
cons: Each region and district are ran independant. They have their own goals and strategies. Do your research and make sure you understand the type of managers you will be working for.

review_title: Stressful and chaotic work environment with little support
pros: You learn a lot about equipment and sales negotiation skills.
cons: Extremely limited holidays and vacation, lack of staff at branches, little support. Pay is mediocre for requiring a bachelor's degree.

review_title: Great company; employee and family oriented; one of the best organization in Corporate America!
pros: Great organization with solid leadership and vision; solid support for people development and diversity.  The company has excellent benefits, and the management, sales, and operations teams have a clear mission: safety, customer satisfaction, and employee development...
cons: It's always a challenge to manage change and programs; but the company goal is to be "best-in-class"; so it's up to us to prioritize all the company initiatives at the local level to deliver in all KPI's

pros: Countless sales tools and opportunities are constantly available. Massive potential for a motivated salesperson.
cons: Company responds to almost every issue or potential risk by adding more paperwork, reporting, procedures, etc. The obsessive pursuit to eliminate all potential risks from the world is constantly deteriorating the quality of service and equipment they are providing.

review_title: Large Employer with a Small Town feel
pros: The visibility of leadership creates a comfortable work environment.  Their investment in their employees & communities shows how much they care. With constant goals of capturing future opportunities in specialty markets, our fleet stays extremely diverse and gives us the tools we need to reach multiple customer profiles and markets.
cons: With an ever changing business model, there creates a lot of movement in management and sales teams.  Can sometimes be hard for customers to maintain a warm trusting relationship

pros:
Good Pay, Great Benefits, Holidays/Sick etc.  Good 401K match, and Medical Spending account match. Good Customers, SOME good people to work with.  Originally a great company to work for, when it was JUST UNITED RENTALS.

 Since the so-called "BUY OUT" of RSC, it's gone completely down hill, as far as their treatment of the hourly or average Joe employee. If you are unfortunate enough to be stuck in a branch that feels more like RSC bought you, you are screwed.  RSC managers are a "buddy club" whose only concerns are for themselves, their big titles, big paychecks & bonuses, and seeing how many new big titles and big paychecks they can create for their old buddies who didn't make the cut. If you aren't part of their click, that includes even up to HR, there is a target on you. Especially if you are BLUE!!  They still hate UR for the buy out, can't understand why, within less than a year of their taking over of our Region, they all had their big titles and big monies back. Then have the nerve to go into the branches and tell hourly employees "United Rentals people make too much money". While they make 6 figure salaries and work 30 hours per week.!!!
cons:
Apathetic, disinterested and very negative Branch, District and Region management. VERY poorly maintained equipment with the new RSC regime.  United used to be know for it's good equipment, and RSC for their raggedy equipment, NOW WE are know for the raggedy stuff.  It's embarrassing.  Can't take pride in what we put out anymore.

Too much BUDDY/Clique RSC system in place. If you aren't in the club, you have to watch your back; even if you do a good job.  If you speak out about the problems OR  voice an opinion contrary to what they want to hear, your days are numbered.
